ygData.subject: Re: Starting smithing...
ygData.msgSnippet: Hail Blacksmiths. I am a warrior of the 16th Tier and was looking to start a trade skill. Since I am a barbarian warrior and fit the mold of what a blacksmith
ygData.messageBody:
Hail Blacksmiths.

I am a warrior of the 16th Tier and was looking to start a trade skill.
Since I am a barbarian warrior and fit the mold of what a blacksmith
'usually' would look like, I have a few basic questions. First, someone
told me that for ANY trade skill, intelligence is of utmost important. Now
I may be strong, but I am pretty simple minded (a 60 intelligence). Should
I even start being a blacksmith with such low smarts? How much will being
'dumb' affect me when trying to increase my skill? I thought about making
another character that would be my blacksmith, but I really don't want to do
the 'mule' thing.

Angarth, Warrior of the 16th Tier
"Periissem ni periisem"


> ----------
> From: XxKommiexX@...[SMTP:XxKommiexX@...]
> Reply To: EQ_Blacksmiths@onelist.com
> Sent: Thursday, June 10, 1999 2:45 PM
> To: EQ_Blacksmiths@onelist.com
> Subject: Re: [EQ_Blacksmiths] Starting smithing...
>
> From: XxKommiexX@...
>
> I disagree. 21 is when bits become trivial. Then make scalers until 41,
> that
> is when they become trivial. Then after that make skewers until 115. That
> is
> when they become trivial. I tried making banded before this, and everyone
> always wanted other banded items. Everyone has gorgets and bracers, they
> are
> the cheapest thing out there. Once 115 make all banded. You will fail a
> lot
> on some things. Sometimes you will have a bad spout. Failing 10 times in a
>
> row at 121 skill in Legs really sucks. once your that high, just keep
> making
> banded. and your skill will raise.
>
> Danthin, Master Smith (123)
> ~Veeshan~
>
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> Campaign 2000 is here!

>
